title: Intertextuality and Canonical Context
objective: Detect how other Scripture texts inform meaning and canonical relationships

required_passages.text: When Israel was a child, I loved him, and out of Egypt I called my son.

Joseph took the child Jesus and His mother by night and fled to Egypt. They remained there until Herod died, so that what was spoken by the Lord through the prophet might be fulfilled: Out of Egypt I called my son.

segments.audio_script: This is lesson five. We'll learn to spot intertextual echoes and canonical links.

Listen to the passage. Hosea 11:1. When Israel was a child, I loved him, and out of Egypt I called my son. Matthew 2:13-15. Joseph took the child Jesus and His mother by night and fled to Egypt. They remained there until Herod died, so that what was spoken by the Lord through the prophet might be fulfilled: Out of Egypt I called my son. Now identify how the earlier text is echoed and developed in later canonical context.
Intertextual references shape theological reading. New Testament authors frequently reread Old Testament passages in light of Christ.
Ask whether the author intentionally cites or alludes to another text. Consider literary markers and shared vocabulary.
Key idea: Scripture interprets Scripture. Canonical context helps locate theological weight of passages.
This completes lesson five. Next lesson teaches weighing secondary sources and commentaries.

vocabulary.definition: The relationship and reference between different biblical texts
